wordpressPost.title: Is Stevia safer than other sugar substitutes?
wordpressPost.content:
Is Stevia safer than other sugar substitutes?

 

They say don’t use artificial sweeteners because they are bad for our health.  They also say not to consume natural sugar because it too is bad for our health.  When it comes to desiring some sweetness in our coffee, tea, cereal or anything else for that matter, is there a safe alternative out there?

I grew up consuming loads of sugar.  My sugar of choice was the drink Coke and well, anything else that I could get my hands on that was sweet.

When I was over at a friends house growing up, they would sometimes have the drink called Tab.  It was sweetened with that pink pack stuff called Sweet N Low.  To me it was pretty good but, to the health industry, it was poison.

As I grew up and started to take better care of my health, I switched from the pink packs to the blue packs of sweeteners called Aspartame.  At the time, it was a safe alternative (so they thought) to the pink packets.

Well, as everyone knows, Aspartame is also not good for our health.  Fast forward to about ten years ago (maybe more, maybe less), the yellow packets came out, and they were called Splenda. Which most of us thought were a safe alternative because Splenda  was “supposed to be made from real sugar.”

Is Stevia safer than other sugar substitutes?

I thought for sure that now, I had a safe alternative to sugar and all the other artificial sweeteners out there.  However, check this out:

“Despite its marketing slogan “Made from sugar, so it tastes like sugar,” Splenda (sucralose) is not sugar. It is a chlorinated artificial sweetener in line with aspartame and saccharin, and with detrimental health effects to match.”

(http://articles.mercola.com/sites/articles/archive/2009/02/10/new-study-of-splenda-reveals-shocking-information-about-potential-harmful-effects.aspx)

When I found out that there was no alternative sweetener that was safe, I did what most people did; I decided to forgo sweeteners along with real sugar for a long time.

I got used to it, but honestly, I missed a little sweeter in my coffee or tea.  So naturally, when Stevia ( a plant-based sweetener) came on the market, I jumped at the chance to use it.

However, I wasn’t going to be fooled by marketing anymore or deceptive advertising that could in the long term, put my health at risk.  I decided to do the research myself to find out how safe Stevia is.

Here is what I found!

“The stevia plant has a long history of use as a sweetener in South America. These new sweeteners—sold under brand names like Truvia and PureVia—include a highly purified extract of stevia called Rebaudioside A (a.k.a. Rebiana or Reb A). Reb A is 200 times sweeter than sugar and does not raise blood sugar.”

“Bottom Line: The FDA considers Reb A a safe sugar substitute, but has not approved other forms of stevia. If you want to use stevia, we suggest sticking with Reb A (look for it on the ingredient label).”

http://www.eatingwell.com/nutrition_health/nutrition_news_information/is_stevia_safe

For me, I will be sure of the quality of my Stevia sweetener by growing it outside on my back deck, alongside all of my other herbs.

Yes, you can get this plant, grow it, muddle the small leaves into your drinks, etc. even dry them out and sprinkle them yourself.

For now, I think that Stevia is a safe alternative to sugar but, that’s what I thought about all of the others too.

I guess I feel a little better about consuming the Stevia plant because I’m growing it and it’s not being processed or manufactured with other chemicals added.

Is Stevia safer than other sugar substitutes?

 If I find out otherwise, I will keep you updated.
